body:
No. :-1: 

For two reasons:
1. I said from the start that I was only ok with the existence of https://github.com/OpenRA/ra2  as long as it doesn't cause work for us (which you very well know, so I really find this PR offensive). This change means that pull requests for ra2 will end up on our main repo, which will definitely cause work and even worse, distractions from our more immediate goals. We already have a hard enough time reviewing all PRs on this repo, this will just make matters worse.
2. I don't see why ra2 has to be the special snow flake that needs to live upstream while a number of other third-party mods do just fine without.

It is now clear to me that allowing https://github.com/OpenRA/ra2 to be created was completely wrong, sent the wrong signal and should have been prevented. The same is probably true for https://github.com/OpenRA/d2. I'm sorry now for taking such a laissez-faire approach and not a more active stance against it when the issue came up half a year ago.

I'm neutral on 2), but I agree on 1).

Edit: Another reason (although 1. is already plenty enough, imo) why this is a bad idea is that without a mod to test this code on (during PR reviews, I mean), the probability of bugs sneaking in is extremely high, and you can't expect reviewers to install the ra2 mod every time to test things properly.
So yeah, :-1: from me too.
I'm closing this, I don't think we should waste time on repeating discussions that will have the same outcome as before anyway.

I did this out of necessity not to put burden onto anyone. The layout in which OpenRA is organized doesn't allow a real modular approach. This gives me two options:
- a) Fork OpenRA as OpenRA2 to focus on RA2 and TS in a combined repository.
- b) Step down from working on RA2 as it is impossible with the current restraints.

My 2 cents, aimed mostly in response to @GraionDilach's comment:

This is a problem that we need to solve for all modders, and myself and @penev92 have done our best towards it (adding support for mod dependencies, oramods, my rejected patch to allow arbitrary support dirs via the commandline), but have received very little engagement from the modder side in return.  The RA2 mod has adopted an "upstream or bust" philosophy, and other mods (like AS, CD, SP) try to work within the current limitations without giving feedback on the issues or how to improve things.

The IRC logs have multiple discussion fragments where I have tried to kickstart mod makefiles that treat the engine as an automatic dependency, but nobody (okay... really just the RA2 mod, since the other modders are never around) is interested.

I am going to try something in https://github.com/OpenRA2 which might either result in a fork where TS and RA2 are the focus and RA/TD/D2k are ignored/removed or everything (mods, engine, tools maybe even dependencies) is stored in it's own repository glued together with git sub-modules.
If you go ahead with this and keep the "OpenRA 2" name without consensus agreement then you risk generating a huge amount of bad will.

I am always open to suggestions. The blue icon might make it easier to distinguish. Hopefully this won't be permanent.

I came up with the best of both worlds. A minimally invasive https://github.com/OpenRA2/OpenRA fork that just adds some project file adjustments and git submodules.
This is a good example of https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cart_before_the_horse.  It is not feasible or sensible to make the core engine project depend on everybody's third party mods.
What do you suggest instead?

The same thing i've been suggesting for months.  Here's two irc excerpts, but there are at least 3 or 4 more.

```
[15:08:08]  <pchote> Mailaender: you'd make life much easier for yourselves if you used the version dependency stuff
[15:08:18]  <pchote> and then had weekly (or whenever you feel like it) update prs
[15:08:40]  <pchote> none of this random breakage and high priority prs to fix it
[15:08:44]  <Mailaender> to work on OpenRA I would then probably need to have 2 repositories
[15:09:38]  <pchote> when working on engine features for ra2 you can just change your ra2-local-engine-fetch script to point to your own repo branch
[15:10:32]  <pchote> in other words: yes, you would, but why is that a problem?
[15:11:43]  <Mailaender> not a problem I assume just a lot of working setting that up again so I probably won't do it
---
[15:12:54]  <Mailaender> feel free to send a pull request 
```

```
[14:35:44]  <pchote> also, theres an obvious technical solution to this
[14:36:02]  <Phrohdoh> Mailaender: You can change the version manually in the mod.yaml, not everything needs to be done by a script.
---
[14:36:36]  <pchote> install the ra2 mod into the support dir, and then have makefile commands to clone and update a local engine version *inside* the ra2 mod dir
---
[14:37:09]  <pchote> if someone ever fixed the ability to specify the support dir on the commandline then it could go anywhere
[14:37:13]  <abcdefg30> submodule's again
[14:37:23]  <pchote> abcdefg30: no, not submodules
[14:37:28]  <pchote> although you could do that too I guess
```

It turned out the problem you were trying to solve with keeping dependencies in mod.yaml isn't such a big issue. The main problem was building the OpenRA.Mod.RA2.dll without OpenRA. The copied or linked dependencies worked, but aren't redistributable. Linking static DLLs causes `TypeLoadExceptions` in the OpenRA engine, see https://github.com/OpenRA/ra2/issues/208 and many people have problems setting up their development environment so git submodules seems to be the easiest way to automate that. I agree that the monolithic structure of the OpenRA project is far from optimal. It has to change at some point.
I explicitly cover that issue in both of the above quotes.  The engine code is cloned to a directory or submodule inside your project dir, and your project file references that.

Something like `$HOME/.openra/mods/ra2/OpenRA/OpenRA.Game.exe` would pretty much violate all sane standards including the placement structures this project adheres to as it puts a duplicate binary inside a user data folder. https://github.com/Phrohdoh/oramod-ra2 went that route. It was abandoned in 2015. Not sure if that simplifies repository setup and is at the same time easy to understand for more and more people who want to try out the development version of the RA2 mod.

If you're developing a mod against an unstable engine then you need to keep a copy of the specific engine version that you need _somewhere_.  Requiring people to manually manage that engine version is what has lead to your current clusterfuck.

You have also missed the part of the quote above where I suggest passing the support / mod dir directly to the engine so that it doesn't need to live in `$HOME/.openra/mods/`.

The idea is to develop against OpenRA bleed so you have just one repository to work with. A throwaway OpenRA version or a second dev repo would limit the possibilities or take extra maintenance work. To solve the problem of incompatible version, we need stable releases of the mod that work with the current or upcoming releases, which also needs this change to produce a OpenRA.Mods.RA2.dll that actually runs outside of a development environment.

How is that supposed to work with the portable support directory? With `ra2/OpenRA/Support/mods/ra2` that would require a recursive backlink to itself. Also have fun writing a tutorial for that setup.

Since I am partially responsible in this PR and it's aftermath:
- I am not supporting this engine fork (and sorry, @Mailaender, I am not accepting that invitation either). Complete forks are IMO the worst overhead possible and the RA2 mod already had that path as well in Phrohdoh/OpenRA.
- I amn't certain what would be the ideal solution nor I am the best modder to provide feedback in terms of mod support, since I am too much of an adjuster by nature. I just know that right now my environment setup (which I converted SP as well weeks ago) works well for me, and only has the overhead of running separate repositories in the same folder, with only rebasing a single commit all the time against upstream - something I am completely fine myself. What I can tell at this point that so far to me, the new mod supporting ideas - like .oramod - are helpful when releasing a mod, but doesn't seem much useful when developing one.
- In any cases, I am planning to return to IRC to somehow give modding support feedback, however lately, I've grinded my PC to a halt (due to some RL reasons) and while I already ordered a new PC (mostly because I had fed up with my GPU performance and the lag resulted from it, which was the main reason why the IRC feedback considered that one AS stream catastrophic back then), it's already two weeks late in deliver and even today I have no idea when I actually will get my hands on it and I don't intend to return to active OpenRA discussions beyond PR reviewing until that computer arrives.

Please try to read and most importantly understand the things I have written above, because i'm getting a bit tired of repeating myself verbatim.

Developing a mod against a moving target is always going to be difficult, you can't avoid that, and the idea of moving this difficulty upstream by making the core engine project reference downstream mod repositories is completely unacceptable.

The proposal I have suggested covers your moving-target use case.  For releasing mods you would obviously not use this, and instead you should be packaging an oramod that is built against a release-tagged engine version.

Okay, I should've looked at the fork. The name must indeed change, but otherwise it follows my setup from what I see and it's not following Phrohdoh/OpenRA. Should have checked it out beforehand I go against it. :S 

@pchote: Up til today, the RA2 mod actually followed the system your second IRC snippet intended albeit crudely (without automating the things). I have a rough guess how to interpret your project setup:

```
/RA2/ (this would be the "support" dir, which has it's own solution, makefile and whatnot, to compile everything in it's /OpenRA/ subfolder, also supplying bats/whatnot to launch /OpenRA.Game.exe with the support dir override)
/RA2/OpenRA (this would be the OpenRA dir which would be forced to take .. as support)
```

Is this really how would it look like though? By shifting all edited coming-from-upstream files a folder above with the structure and then taking them from a relative path during compiling?

The location doesn't really matter, it could be `/RA2/OpenRA`, `/RA2/dependencies/engine`, `/OpenRA-RA2`, `/var/temp/<random string>`, or anything else you could dream of.  The key points are that (1) it is a directory that is understood to be owned and managed by the mod's makefile and treated as a thirdparty dependency and (2) that it is a known path so that you can reference the binaries from your ra2 project files.

You then build your makefile commands to automatically manage that self-contained engine version based on metadata that you define for the RA2 mod.  I've been suggesting that you use the mod.yaml dependency line so that you only need to set the upstream version in one place, but that appears to have caused at least some confusion.

You then modify the upstream engine code to define some way to run your self-contained engine copy with an arbitrary mod path, either by setting the support directory, overloading the Game.Mod parsing to accept a path as well as an ID, or any other solution that works for you.

Okay, I think I got it. This means that the mod.yaml dependency line would refer to an exact commit, which would be checked out by the mod's make script, which can just simply compile the upstream dependencies, engine, and version them thenafter.

I have to acknowledge that such a setup would actually make the OpenRA/RA2 repository the most efficient one.

Exactly.  You can use the `git-<shorthash>` version that is automatically generated by `make version`, and just trim off the leading `git-` to get the commit hash to check out.  You can then run the standard `make version` on the checked out engine code to set up the yaml metadata for the mod chooser so that you get the additional protection of the runtime version check.

Okay, if nothing else comes in, I will try to get this setup implemented in an OpenRA/RA2 branch tomorrow (gotta abuse the push rights if I have them :P). However to make this system working seamlessly, #10981 needs to be merged beforehand.

I would rather prefer something like https://git.eclipse.org/c/platform/eclipse.platform.releng.aggregator.git/tree/, but git doesn't support nested sub-modules which we would need for a twisted OpenRA directory layout.

As above, solutions that rely on an upstream repository referencing downstream mods are not viable or acceptable.  It is a selfish solution that effectively says that we only support specially nominated mods and that we don't care about anyone else.

Not just that, this current proposal has the potential to end the - now habitual - "revamp the RA2 mod setup every fourth month" with bringing in an automated and as-user-friendly-as-upstream setup introductions with an acceptable overhead (have a second OpenRA upstream downloaded) a lot of mod maintainers already have, without going overly complicated.

I guess I'm sold on it now. I do have to demand for #10981 to get it done, though.
Tibsun isn't being shipped.
Neither tibsun or ra2 are anywhere near done enough to ship to our tens of thousands of players.
